liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Only one defendant remains on trial over the deadly White Island disaster after a judge dismissed charges against two companies this morning. ID Tours Limited and Tauranga Tourism Services were local agents that formed part of the supply chain between tourists from the Ovation of the Seas cruise ship and White Island. They were among the 13 parties charged with breaches of New Zealand's workplace health and safety laws after 22 people died when Whakaari erupted in December 2019. Last week, the two companies applied to have charges against them dismissed and today Judge Evangelos Thomas granted that application. “Neither Tauranga Tourism nor ID Tours had workers on Whakaari, it was never their workplace, they did not influence or direct the workers of the tour operators in the carrying out of their work,” he said while delivering his ruling in Auckland. Also last week, the owners of the volcano Peter, Andrew and Peter Buttle had charges against them dismissed. Their company Whakaari Management Limited is the only party that remains on trial. Five other defendants pleaded guilty before the trial began and a sixth had charges dismissed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More charges dismissed in White Island trial

featuredLink.title: More White Island tourism companies have charges dismissed

children.content: Only one defendant remains on trial over the deadly White Island disaster after

13 parties charged with breaches of New Zealand's workplace health and safety laws

in the carrying out of their work,” he said while delivering his ruling in Auckland.
Also last week, the
owners of the volcano

had

Their company
Whakaari Management Limited
is the
only party that remains on trial.
Five other defendants pleaded guilty before the trial began and a sixth had charges dismissed.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Portuguese computer hacker, who revealed financial irregularities in elite soccer across Europe, has been handed a four-year suspended prison sentence. Rui Pinto was found guilty by a court in Lisbon of attempted extortion and illegally accessing data. His discoveries led to Cristiano Ronaldo being fined for tax evasion and an investigation into Manchester City's accounts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Portuguese 'whistleblower' behind Football Leaks Rui Pinto handed suspended sentence

props.alt: A man in a suit inside a court room.

children.content: (Reuters: Pedro Nunes)
A Portuguese computer hacker, who revealed financial irregularities in elite soccer across Europe, has been handed a four-year suspended prison sentence.
Rui Pinto was found guilty by a court in Lisbon of attempted extortion and illegally accessing data.
His discoveries led to Cristiano Ronaldo being fined for tax evasion and an
investigation into Manchester City's accounts.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rescuers pulled an American researcher out of a Turkish cave on Monday, more than a week after he became seriously ill 1,000 metres below its entrance. Teams from across Europe had rushed to Morca cave in southern Türkiye’s Taurus Mountains to aid Mark Dickey, a 40-year-old experienced caver who became seriously ill on September 2 with stomach bleeding. He was on an expedition to map the cave, which is the country’s third deepest. Mr Dickey was too frail to climb out himself, so rescuers carried him with the help of a stretcher, making frequent stops at temporary camps set up along the way. “Mark Dickey is out of the Morca cave. He is fine and is being tended to by emergency medical worker in the encampment above,” said a statement by the speleological federation on Monday. "Thus, the cave rescue part of the operation has ended successfully. We congratulate all those who have contributed!” AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US researcher has been rescued from deep Turkish cave after more than a week

featuredLink.title: American researcher who fell ill has been rescued from 1,000 metres deep in Turkish cave

props.alt: Rescuers pulling a man out of a cave

children.content: (AP: CNSAS)
Rescuers pulled an American researcher out of a Turkish cave on Monday, more than a week after he became seriously ill 1,000 metres below its entrance.

Teams from across Europe had rushed to Morca cave in southern Türkiye’s Taurus Mountains to aid Mark Dickey, a 40-year-old experienced caver who became seriously ill on September 2 with stomach bleeding.
He was on an expedition to map the cave, which is the country’s third deepest.
Mr Dickey was too frail to climb out himself, so rescuers carried him with the help of a stretcher, making frequent stops at temporary camps set up along the way.
“Mark Dickey is out of the Morca cave. He is fine and is being tended to by emergency medical worker in the encampment above,” said a statement by the speleological federation on Monday.
"Thus, the cave rescue part of the operation has ended successfully. We congratulate all those who have contributed!”
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is lower in early trade despite a good night on Wall Street. The benchmarket ASX 200 ended higher yesterday after four days of losses. The ASX 200 index is down 0.1 per cent to 7,184. Most sectors are lower led down by energy stocks. Miners have gained after good economic data from China yesterday. Here are the best and worst performers: Telix Pharmaceutical: +4.6% Megaport: +4.3% Pilbara Minerals: +2.8% Syrah Resources: -4.9% Viva Energy: -4.8% Lovisa: -3.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian shares in the red in early trade

children.content: The Australian share market is lower in early trade despite a good night on Wall Street.
The benchmarket ASX 200 ended higher yesterday after four days of losses.
The ASX 200 index is down 0.1 per cent to 7,184.
Most sectors are lower led down by energy stocks.
Miners have gained after good economic data from China yesterday.
Here are the best and worst performers:
Telix Pharmaceutical: +4.6%
Megaport: +4.3%
Pilbara Minerals: +2.8%
Syrah Resources: -4.9%
Viva Energy: -4.8%
Lovisa: -3.6%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: State and federal politicians rank poorly on an ethics index, just above real estate agents. A survey from the Governance Institute says while the perception of politicians has improved, they still rank in the five bottom professions. Journalists are also in the bottom 10 but rank better than social media platforms and payday lenders. The overall Ethics Index score returned to the 2021 figure of 45, having taken a tumble last year. The most ethical occupations were fire services, followed by ambulance services and pharmacists. Governance Institute chief executive Megan Motto spoke to senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Politicians ranked just above real estate agents on ethics

children.content: State and federal politicians rank poorly on an ethics index, just above real estate agents.
A survey from the
Governance Institute
says while the perception of politicians has improved, they still rank in the five bottom professions.
Journalists are also in the bottom 10 but rank better than social media platforms and payday lenders.
The overall Ethics Index score returned to the 2021 figure of 45, having taken a tumble last year.
The most ethical occupations were fire services, followed by ambulance services and pharmacists.
Governance Institute chief executive Megan Motto spoke to senior business correspondent
Peter Ryan.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Billionaire Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting has become a substantial shareholder in lithium miner Liontown Resources. The move comes after Liontown accepted a $6.6 billion takeover bid from global lithium giant Albemarle. There was speculation last week that Hancock would launch a rival takeover bid for Liontown. Hancock told the ASX that it had become a substantial shareholder in Liontown, lifting its 4.9 per cent stake to 7.72 per cent. And it says may seek a seat on the Liontown board. In a statement Hancock Prospecting said: "This shareholding provides Hancock with a strategic stake in Liontown, giving Liontown the opportunity to leverage Hancock's expertise where it is of value to support the (Kathleen Valley lithium) project's development and subsequent operations." "Hancock can contribute to Liontown's future direction alongside other Liontown shareholders, including in relation to potential investment opportunities for downstream value add in West Australia." The move is Ms Rinehart's biggest investment in lithium so far. She has stakes in Vulcan Energy and Delta Lithium, and a lithium joint venture with Indian miner NMDC.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gina Rinehart increases stake in Liontown Resources

children.content: Billionaire Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting
has become a substantial shareholder in lithium miner
Liontown Resources.
The move comes after Liontown accepted a $6.6 billion takeover bid from global lithium giant Albemarle.
There was speculation last week that Hancock would launch a rival takeover bid for Liontown.
Hancock told the ASX that it had become a substantial shareholder in Liontown, lifting its 4.9 per cent stake to 7.72 per cent.
And it says may seek a seat on the Liontown board.
In a statement Hancock Prospecting said:

"This shareholding provides Hancock with a strategic stake in Liontown, giving Liontown the opportunity to leverage Hancock's expertise where it is of value to support the (Kathleen Valley lithium) project's development and subsequent operations."
"Hancock can contribute to Liontown's future direction alongside other Liontown shareholders, including in relation to potential investment opportunities for downstream value add in West Australia."
The move is Ms Rinehart's biggest investment in lithium so far.
She has stakes in Vulcan Energy and Delta Lithium, and a lithium joint venture with Indian miner NMDC.
